node.title: Internet issues in Tonga pose challenge for workers trying to come to NZ
node.description: Poor internet access in Tonga because of last month's eruption and tsunami is putting massive pressure, stress and strain on seasonal workers trying to come to Aotearoa for the pipfruit harvest.

node.title: Black Fern leads Matatū leaders into Super Rugby Aupiki
node.description: Black Fern Alana Bremner will lead the South Island wāhine in the Super Rugby Aupiki competition surrounded by other strong leaders.

node.title: Freightways delivers $43.7m half-year profit
node.description: Information management, freight and courier business Freightways has reported a strong first half, despite challenges posed Covid-19 lockdowns.

node.title: Poll: More Americans would rather meet Lincoln than Washington
node.description: Lincoln is preferred across demographic groups.

node.title: Sarah Hirini to captain Hurricanes in Super Rugby Aupiki
node.description: Black Ferns Sevens gold medallist Sarah Hirini will captain the Hurricanes in the inaugural Super Rugby Aupiki competition.

node.title: City mourns Huntington Beach police officer who died in helicopter crash
node.description: Dive teams had been in the water all day searching for clues about what caused the helicopter to crash just feet from the busy shore.

node.title: Some of biggest firms' earnings expected to show tough results
node.description: The floodgates of company earnings open this week, with close to 30 companies set to report, and some of the numbers from some of the biggest companies may be tough reading.

node.title: Hospitality in crisis due to lack of domestic travel
node.description: Hospitality New Zealand says domestic travel is at a standstill with forward bookings pointing to accommodation occupancy rates as low as 20 percent for the next three months.

node.title: Rage against the machine: Can an AI programme be an inventor?
node.description: New Zealand has been caught by a global fight between humans and machines that might define intellectual property rights for the rest of the century.

node.title: Cabinet-level official afflicted with "Havana Syndrome" injuries
node.description: U.S. officials say they were stricken with vertigo, confusion, and memory loss both at home and work in Washington, D.C.

node.title: 'Hopefully they would ... see what they're being used for'
node.description: The protesters at Parliament are certainly not all far-right activists - but those who aren't risk being radicalised into committing violence, a researcher says. Audio

node.title: The situation inside Ukraine as Russian forces loom
node.description: Lesley Stahl speaks with Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba about how his country is handling Russia's increasing aggression.

node.title: Working from home likely to last beyond pandemic - expert
node.description: The line between home and work has blurred, with so many forced to work from home during the pandemic. Could a culture change be looming?

node.title: Police install concrete blocks around Parliament anti-mandate protest
node.description: Hundreds of police staff have cordoned off the protest at Parliament in a bid to open some of the roads back up to Wellington.

node.title: Parliament protest deadlock - where to from here?
node.description: Two weeks in and the occupation of Parliament remains a total stalemate with no sign protesters are going anywhere. So where to from here?

node.title: Fight erupts after Michigan basketball coach takes swing at Wisconsin assistant
node.description: Several players also appeared to throw punches in the ensuing fight.

node.title: Covid-19: Rapid antigen tests rolled out at testing centres
node.description: Community Covid testing centres in Auckland will begin giving some people rapid antigen tests from today.

node.title: Tougher controls on carbon farming outlined in discussion paper
node.description: The paper outlined the risk that short-term land-use decisions would be made to the detriment of long-term land-use flexibility, rural communities and export returns.

node.title: Beijing Winter Olympics come to an end
node.description: Beijing has doused its Olympic flame closing a Games that will be remembered for the extremes of its anti-Covid-19 measures and outrage over a doping scandal.

node.title: Emergency departments seeing 'extreme' number of patients
node.description: An experienced nurse says conditions at Palmerston North Hospital's emergency department are pushing staff to their limits.

node.title: Principals fight plan to restrict enrolment of foreign students
node.description: Primary school principals say the proposal does not make sense and comes just as foreign families are lining up to enrol their children next year after borders reopen.

node.title: Mendis fifty helps Sri Lanka to avoid clean sweep against Australia
node.description: Opener Kusal Mendis struck an unbeaten 69 off 58 balls to help secure a consolation five-wicket victory for Sri Lanka over Australia in the fifth and final T20.

node.title: Ukraine mark anniversary of deadly uprising as threat of Russian invasion looms
node.description: "I think that the Ukrainian people has made its decision, and I don't think that Russia is in a position to overturn it," one protestor said at a memorial service Sunday.

node.title: 'Being agile': Call for Covid-19 home isolation period to be shortened
node.description: The current Covid-19 home isolation rules are overkill and need to be cut to three days for vaccinated people without symptoms, a leading doctor says.

node.title: 'Zero privacy' for ED patients waiting in corridors due to health system capacity
node.description: Emergency department corridor waits were supposed to be abolished years ago but doctors say the problem is hitting crisis levels again because hospitals are so clogged.

node.title: Is NZ's film industry ready for the digital screen revolution?
node.description: The Detail - Virtual production technologies and digital screens are set to change the way movies are made, but is New Zealand's film industry ready?

node.title: Full transcript of "Face the Nation" on February 20, 2022
node.description: On this "Face the Nation" broadcast, Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Russian Ambassador to the U.S. Anatoly Antonov join Margaret Brennan.

node.title: Woods won't be drawn on Masters
node.description: Tiger Woods has reiterated that he fully intends to return to the PGA Tour, he just doesn't know when.

node.title: What's on Mahuta's agenda for 11-day overseas trip
node.description: Foreign Minister Nanaia Mahuta says New Zealand reconnecting with the world will be a focus of her new 11-day mission to Europe.

node.title: Super Rugby Pacific: Hurdles, TMO troubles and tiny changing rooms
node.description: History was made as the Chiefs and Highlanders kicked off at the Wakatipu RFC, writes Jamie Wall. Video
